moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 N: The Sozin Sicilian, a line that regained popularity in the 1960's as the Richter-Rauzer attack was analyzed to seeming exhaustion.
moves.6... e6 7. Be3 Be7 8. Qe2: A relatively new idea, the Velimirovic attack leads to very sharp play.
moves.8... O-O 9. Bb3 Qc7 10. O-O-O a6 11. Rhg: An excellent move, taking away Black's primary drawing resource [11... NxN] and avoiding early endgames.
moves.11... b5: At the time this game was played, this was considered the sharpest move.
moves.12. g4 b4 13. Nxc6 Qxc6 14. Nd5: Based on the weakness of the long diagonal.
moves.14... exd5 15. g5: The only way to continue the attack.
moves.15... dxe4: Considered the best move, both then and now.
moves.17... Qa4: It was thought at the time this was played that Black stood well. If 18 BxR. 18... B-K3! 19 B-Q4 BxB 20 RxB QxRP is good for Black.
moves.18. Qh5 Be6: Black has no choice (18... P-N3? 19 RxP ch! RPxR 20 QxP ch B-N2 21 B-Q4!)
moves.19. Rxg7+ Bxg7 20. Rg1 Rfc8 21. Rxg7+ Kx: If 21... K-B1, 22 RxP ch forces mate.
moves.22. Qh6+ Kg8 23. Bxe4: Here is the quiet move. White stops the mate on his QB2 and takes aim at KR7. A few variations will show the depth of White's conception: (a) 23... RxP ch 24 BxR R-QB1 25 QxP ch K-B-1 26 Q-R8 ch K-K2 27 B-N5 ch K-Q2 28 QxR ch Any 29 BxQ. (b) 23... QxP ch 24 BxQ B-B4 25 B-Q4 RxB ch 26 K-Q1 P-B3 27 QxBP and wins. (c) 23... R-B4 24 BxP ch K-R1 25 B-B5 ch K-N1 26 B-Q4 R-K4 27 BxR PxB 28 Q-R7 ch K-B1 29 BxB PxB 30 Q-R8 ch and after winning the Rook White has the better of the Q and P ending.
moves.23... b3: This sets up counterplay based on ...PxRP.
moves.26... Kf8 27. Bh6+ Ke8 28. Qg8+ Ke7: Black is trying to avoid walking into a pin.
moves.29. Bg5+ Kd7 30. Qxf7+ Kc6 31. Bxe6: Here Black is lost despite the lively appearance of his position. On 31... QxP, for example, White wins by 32 Q-Q7 ch K-N3 33 B-K3 ch K-R4 34 B-Q2 ch K-N3 35 QxP ch R-B3 36 B-K3 ch K-N2 37 Q-Q7 ch R-B2 38 B-Q5 ch K-N1 39 Q-Q8 ch R-B1 40 Q-N6 mate. Another way to go is 31... R-B2 32 B-Q5 ch K-N3 33 B-K3 ch R-B4 34 Q-N7 ch K-R4 35 B-Q2 ch winning everything. The Bishops are sheer murder.
moves.31... Kb6 32. Be3+ Ka5: There is no longer any viable defense.
moves.36. Bb4+: 36 RPxP was good enough, but this simplification ends all Black's potential counterplay.
moves.36... Kxb4 37. a3+ Kc4 38. Qxb5+ axb5 39: White seizes the opposition. Black resigns at once, as the K and P ending is hopeless.
